As editor of Foreign Policy Journal, I receive a lot of submissions about the situation in Ukraine, many of which parrot the claim of Western governments that Russia has sent in its military to support the separatists.

Every time, I reply to the author asking for evidence to support their claim.

To date, no one has been able to do so.

In the most recent instance, after several failed attempts, the author admitted he can't support the claim with any actual evidence. He went on to insist it is true anyway, and then proceeded to insult me for being "naive" and engaging in "negationism".

In my reply, I let him know it was precisely that kind of lazy and irresponsible journalism that served to manufacture consent for the war on Iraq and that I wasn't going to lower FPJ's standard just to accommodate his work.

Anyhow, it's been enlightening for me as an editor to frequently encounter this.
Official conspiracy theories are accepted as true, but everyone who questions them is a "conspiracy theorist."

This article illustrates what I like about Peter Beinart's commentaries and what I dislike about them. He does a pretty good job of responding to Dennis Ross's nonsense in his recent NYT op-ed portraying the Palestinians as the obstacle to peace. Then he closes by saying that by appealing to the ICC, the Palestinians are "doing it the Zionist way". 

No, Peter. Appealing to the international community and international law are not "the Zionist way". 

The Zionist way was to ethnically cleanse Palestine of 750,000 of its inhabitants to further the racist goal of establishing a "Jewish state" in its place. 

The Zionist way has been to try to brutalize and oppress the Palestinians into submission to cement their gains, such as their illegally-constructed colonies in the West Bank, or simply to punish them for existing, as with their longstanding policy of collectively punishing the entire civilian population of Gaza.

No, Peter, what the Palestinians are doing is nothing at all like the Zionist way. It is pretty much the opposite of that.
